comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: We may be able to date this photograph. The scaffolded spire is of Christ Church St. Laurence. The spire was completed in 1855, however this photograph was taken much later than 1855, from the clothes and trams. On 18 August 1905, there was a serious fire in the Church, after which major reconstruction was undertaken, including work on the spire. The restored church was reopened on 14 April 1906. Hence this photograph would have been taken between those two dates. Here is the story of the reconstruction: www.ccsl.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=vie... Here is a matching photograph from 1905 of the scaffolded spire: www.ccsl.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=vie...

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: next doors marcus Clarkes tower was completed in 1906. so that may help. at the time is was sydneys tallest at 43m high.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Similar view a few years earlier (late 1890's, no Marcus Clarke building): www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/history/sydneystreets/Then_&a... The "octagonal Jennings Patent 6 person cast iron urinal" has disappeared in this later picture!

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: ^that photo is great. see the hghrise building behind St Laurence. thats the furniture warehouse of anthony horderns.it was sydneys tallest when completed in 1893. its 7 storeys rose 40m high. it sadly burnt down in july 1901.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks uminarampart, I wondered what it was.
